terms.definition: Quality Assurance - a systematic process of ensuring that products or services meet specified requirements and standards
A software system that facilitates the creation, storage, organization, and sharing of organizational knowledge and information
A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or code over time, allowing users to revert to previous versions and track revision history
Good Manufacturing Practices - a set of regulations and guidelines that ensure pharmaceutical products are consistently produced and controlled according to quality standards
The ability for multiple users to work simultaneously on the same document or project with changes visible instantly to all participants
The use of software to automatically execute repetitive tasks and processes without manual intervention
Enterprise Resource Planning - integrated software systems that manage and automate core business processes across an organization
Quality Management System - a formalized system that documents processes, procedures, and responsibilities for achieving quality policies and objectives
A unified approach to storing all documents and information in a single, accessible location rather than scattered across multiple systems
The process of ensuring that business practices and documentation adhere to relevant laws, regulations, and industry standards
Food and Drug Administration - the U.S. federal agency responsible for regulating and supervising the safety of drugs, medical devices, and other consumer products
European Medicines Agency - the European Union's regulatory body responsible for the evaluation and supervision of medicinal products
A system feature that automatically creates copies of documents and data at regular intervals to prevent data loss
Digital environments where team members can collaborate, access shared documents, and communicate on projects in a centralized location
The process of connecting different software applications and systems to work together and share data seamlessly
